definitions: A piece of paper that is empty and has not been drawn on or written on yet, like a clean slate ready to be filled with ideas or drawings.

model_response: Okay! Imagine you have a big piece of meat, like a chicken breast or a piece of beef. Now, if you take that meat and chop it up into really, really tiny pieces—so tiny that it looks like little bits—that’s called **mince**! It’s like turning the meat into teeny-tiny crumbs. People use mince to make yummy things like meatballs, burgers, or spaghetti sauce. It’s just a way to make the meat easier to cook and eat! 😊
definitions: Chopping meat into really tiny pieces, like little bits or crumbs, to make it easier to cook and eat

model_response: Okay! Imagine you have a shiny gold star sticker. It’s when people think you’re really good and kind because you do the right thing, even when it’s hard. So, honor is like being a superhero of kindness and doing what’s right! 🌟
definitions: A feeling inside when people think you are good and kind for doing the right thing, even when it's hard

model_response:
Okay! Imagine you have a toy car, and you want to make sure it can drive really fast without falling apart. So, you take it to a little track and push it as fast as you can to see what happens. That’s like a *test*!  

A test is when you try something out to see if it works the way it’s supposed to. It’s like checking your toy car, or even your crayons to make sure they color nicely. Testing helps us know if something is ready to use or if it needs fixing. Cool, right? 🚗✨
definitions: Trying something out to see if it works the way it's supposed to, like checking a toy car or crayons.

model_response:
Okay! Imagine you have a big box of crayons, but you only have a few favorite colors you like to use all the time. The other crayons in the box are still there, but you don’t use them as much. Those extra crayons are like "filler." They fill up the box, but they’re not the main ones you care about.

In stories, games, or even TV shows, "filler" is stuff that’s added to take up space or time, but it’s not super important to the main story or fun part. It’s like those extra crayons—they’re there, but they’re not the stars of the show!
definitions: Extra items that fill up space but are not the main focus, like crayons you don't use as much
In stories, games, or TV shows, filler refers to content added to take up time or space that isn't important to the main part

model_response: Okay! Imagine you have a toy that you really, really love, but it’s been sitting in the corner for a long time, and no one is playing with it. It’s just sitting there, feeling sad and forgotten. That’s kind of what "languish" means—it’s when something or someone is stuck, not growing, not happy, and just waiting for something to happen. It’s like when you’re bored and don’t know what to do, and time feels really slow. That’s languishing!
definitions: When something or someone is stuck, not growing, and feeling sad or forgotten, like a toy that no one plays with.

model_response:
Okay! Imagine you’re playing a game of hide-and-seek, and you’re hiding in a closet. Suddenly, you hear someone coming to find you! You don’t want to be caught, so you quietly sneak out of the closet and run away to a new hiding spot. That’s like an *escape*—you’re getting away from something or somewhere to stay safe or free.

In real life, "escape" means getting away from something you don’t like or that might be scary or dangerous. It’s like when you’re in a loud, noisy room and you go outside to a quiet place—you’re escaping the noise to feel better! 😊
definitions: Getting away from something or somewhere to stay safe or free, like sneaking out of a closet in hide-and-seek
Getting away from something you don’t like or that might be scary or dangerous, like leaving a noisy room for a quiet place

model_response: Okay! Imagine you have a toy that makes a loud noise when you press a button. That noise is called a "bang!" It’s a sudden, loud sound that can surprise you, like when a balloon pops or a drum is hit really hard. So, "bang" is just a word we use to describe that kind of big, exciting noise! 💥
definitions: A sudden, loud sound that can surprise you, like when a balloon pops or a drum is hit really hard

model_response: Okay! Imagine you’re playing a game, and things get a little too hard or scary. A "retreat" is like taking a step back to a safe place where you can rest, think, and feel better. It’s not giving up—it’s just taking a break so you can come back stronger later. Like when you’re playing tag and you run to a safe spot to catch your breath. That’s a retreat!
definitions: Taking a step back to a safe place to rest and feel better, like when playing a game and needing a break.

model_response:
Okay! Imagine you have a big box where you keep all your favorite toys. Every time you find a new toy that you really like, you put it in the box. You keep adding more and more toys to your box because you love collecting them!

A **collector** is someone who does something like that, but instead of toys, they might collect things like stamps, coins, rocks, or even stickers. They find things they really like and keep them all together in a special place. It’s like having a treasure box full of things that make them happy! 🌟
definitions: A person who keeps and gathers things they really like, such as stamps, coins, rocks, or stickers, in a special place like a treasure box.

model_response:
Okay! Imagine you’re playing with your toy cars, and you’re driving them really fast. If two cars bump into each other really hard, they might break or make a big noise—that’s a crash! 

In real life, a crash happens when something, like a car, bike, or even a computer, stops working suddenly because it got hit or something went wrong. It’s like when your toy car stops moving because it hit the wall too hard. We don’t want crashes to happen, so we try to be careful!
definitions: A sudden bump or collision between objects, like toy cars, that can break them or make a loud noise
A situation where something stops working suddenly due to being hit or malfunctioning, like a car or computer

model_response: Okay! Imagine you have some toys, and you want to know how many you have in total. "Calculate" is like using your brain to figure out the answer. For example, if you have 2 teddy bears and 3 toy cars, you can *calculate* by adding them together: 2 + 3 = 5. So, you have 5 toys in all! Calculating is just a fancy word for figuring things out with numbers or steps. It’s like solving a little puzzle! 🧩✨
definitions: Using your brain to figure out the answer to how many things you have by adding numbers together, like 2 teddy bears and 3 toy cars to get 5 toys.

model_response:
Okay! Imagine you have a toy that makes a sound when you press a button. When you press the button, it goes "click!" and something happens, like a light turning on or a song playing. 

On a computer or a phone, a "click" is like pressing a button, but instead of using your finger on a toy, you use a mouse or tap the screen. When you click, it tells the computer to do something, like open a game, play a video, or show a picture. So, a click is just a way to tell the computer, "Hey, do this thing for me!"
definitions: A sound made when pressing a button on a toy or device, which can cause something to happen, like a light turning on or a song playing
An action on a computer or phone where you use a mouse or tap the screen to tell the device to do something, like open a game or play a video
